reviewText: I grew up with these movies.  I watched all of them numerous times in my life.  Watching them was simply wonderful.  If you lived through these days you will want the whole collection.  If you don't know what they are,  they are wonderful action serial films from the early days of science fiction.

reviewText: New what to expect from past serial films so it was no surprise when I started to watch this. For what it is I would say to remember the last serial that you viewed before you make a move to purchase. Pictures quality  varies from a + to a - throughout the shows.Acting reminds me of watching an Arnold picture i.e. I'll be back. C6
Title: N/A

reviewText: I've only watched the first two adventures (am going to start 'Flash Gordon's Trip to Mars' this weekend). Picture is very good considering how long ago it was made. Sound is a little fuzzy in spots. I received this very quickly and in perfect shape. Price is so low that it's hard to believe. The story is nothing special - mostly typical serial fun with (sometimes) hard to believe escapes and rescues.I actually purchased this after ordering and watching 'Buck Rogers'. Since I liked that so much I did some research and ordered this gem.Today audiences will most likely find the 'special effects' not so special. But you have to keep in mind WHEN they was made and what they had to work with PLUS the amount of money they had budgeted. Considering all of that the special effects aren't that bad. I'm not saying they're good but they did what was intended - they moved the story along. After all this is as much a 'fantasy' as a Sci-Fi production.You have to reconcile having space ships and the lack of technology otherwise.And, of course, the stupidity of the evil henchmen.BUT this is part of the charm of this kind of 'movie'. I was not around when this was made (I was born in 1952) but I enjoy the serials. I've just received 'King of the Rocketmen'. I remember watching that one with my dad when he would get home around 2AM Sat mornings from work. I would just be coming home from a date, etc and he would often sat down and watch this kind of show with me then. It's memories like that that enhance watching these kinds of movies.I would rate this a very solid 8.0 out of 10.
summary: Very good for a something made 70 years ago!

reviewText: The final chapters of this serial seem to be missing; however, they are on another disc. I thought that they'd been omitted until I carefully compared the table of contents to what was on the discs. So, the falling action and climax are out of order; but not to despair. Seek an ye shall find.
summary: Be aware of the misplaced final chapters.

reviewText: Love the show, and the video quality is fine.But the person who designed this package should be shot.The case is taller than a DVD case which means it doesn't fit on standard DVD shelves.To make it worse, the disc holder mechanism don't work - my shipment arrived with loos and scratched discs.Luckily, after 2 returns, I was able to cobble together 4 undamaged DVDs.Also the center booklet is stapled to the case, and arrived loose (ripped out at the staple locations).Cool idea - horrible execution.

reviewText: I watched Flash Gordon way back in the middle to late 1950’s when I was about 10 to 12 years old. Now, seeing it after such a long time spanning 63 years, the person who played Ming stared also in some Our Gang movies, I think.

reviewText: This is one of the best serials ever made but the copies leave a lot to be desired. The film sources of each were not of good quality and it really shows! The first one is is the worst (1936). They do get better in the second and third stories (1938 and 1940) but are still not very good in quality. They will work in a pinch but with today's big screen systems, the DVD producers needs to research some high quality originals (they're out there) and present these true cliffhangers in the quality they deserve.
Title: N/A

reviewText: These are the classic "Flash Gordon" serials from Universal, starring Buster Crabbe in the title role, with Charles Middleton as Emperor Ming "The Merciless" and Frank Shannon as Dr. Alexis Zarkov.  The first two, "Flash Gordon" (1936) and "Flash Gordon's Trip to Mars" (1938) have Jean Rogers as Dale Arden, and Richard Alexander as Prince Barin, with Carol Hughes and Roland Drew in these roles for the last serial, "Flash Gordon Conquers the Universe" (1940).  The acting, special effects and other aspects of these are thoroughly discussed elsewhere; I'll just note that the appearance of the Flash Gordon comic strip may well have provoked over-the-top serials like "The Lost City" and "The Phantom Empire," and Universal was ready for these classics, having made the first comic strip adaptation with "Tailspin Tommy" in 1934.This "Collectable Video-Book" is by Image/Madacy Home Entertainment, # VB9 51292, the discs being the same ones first issued by Image in 1999 with only the labels changed to match the new packaging.  They are numbered a little oddly; disc 1 has the first serial, but the second serial is on discs 3 and 4 owing to the layout of the package.  At least they are labelled correctly.  Included is a 24-page booklet, "Flash Gordon & the Golden Age of Comic Strips," with text by David Fiore and containing a number of illustrations from the comic strip by Alex Raymond, which is an "extra feature" not present in the old set, though the down side is that the package is 3/4 inch taller than a standard DVD case or VHS tape.  The discs are stored in pockets in the cardboard cover, with a soft plastic piece holding them at the center hole; they are not especially easy to remove and could easily get damaged in the process.  The cardboard folder doesn't latch closed, and there is no outer sleeve provided, so the discs are not protected as well against dust as they would be in normal cases.  Still, the package thickness is about the same as a standard DVD case, taking less horizontal space than the old set.As for the discs, the picture quality is decent, for existing prints of Universal serials, sharp and with mostly-good gray scale, though no extensive clean-up has been done.  There are small scratches and dirt, some of which is from the original negatives, and a few scenes are a little bright, with highlights slightly washed out.  The first serial has an increase in the number of scratches near the ends of the reels, noticed mostly at the mid-point of some chapters.  The titles of "Flash Gordon's Trip to Mars" are rather grainy, but the chapters themselves show less of the problem.  The sound is clear enough for the dialogue to be understood, but the first two serials have some speed glitches, "wow" or intermittent sticking of the soundtrack heard mostly in the music of the credits.  It is worse in "Flash Gordon's Trip to Mars" where the instability can even be heard in the "rocket motors" sputtering through the air.  This serial is also still missing the 70-second piece from Chapter 3 where the pursuing Stratosled is shot down by Flash and Zarkov, though it was included in the "Space Soldiers' Trip to Mars" version run for many years on television.  The third serial, "Flash Gordon Conquers the Universe" has the best print quality.  Those complaining about a grainy image are most likely observing the truly dreadful quality of Universal's stock footage, especially that from the 1929 German film "Die Weisse Hölle vom Pitz Palü" ("The White Hell of Pitz Palu") used extensively for the avalanche rescue scenes in Frigia, where Flash and party have gone to find "Polarite."  Grain can become fairly intolerable if the sharpness enhancement levels are excessive in the monitor and DVD player.  The old film also shows some flicker, and a clip from it appears in the opening titles.  Fortunately such "defects" have not been "corrected" in the Image edition; it appears as it would have in the theatre.The included booklet is entertaining, if not a great wealth of information, and the package is worthwhile for those who don't already have the earlier DVD set from Image.  I had hoped that some effort would have been put into correcting the defects in the film prints, but these serials are a lot of fun, when watched with time between the chapters, and at least they remain available in generally good transfers.  I think that's enough for a 4-star "I Like It" rating.
summary: Classic Serials!  New Package!  Same Old Discs...

reviewText: There are a couple of issues with the transfer, but all in all a splendid job in getting these adventures from the big screen to the somewhat smaller one.The booklet is nice, but not very in-depth or far-ranging.However, I have to applaud the effort to bring the horror of Ming (the Merciless) and his ruthless, nay villainous machinations back to the viewing public.
summary: Quick Zarkof, Give Me The Nitron Gun!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Deliciously un-PC "Yellow Peril" sci-fi, the definitive pre-Star Wars movie space opera.  Charles Middleton ()remember him from "Duck Soup?") is a scene-stealer, not that Crabbe is much competition. As close as we're going to get to a screen version of Jack Williamson's "Legion of Space."  Between the TV broadcasts of this and Disney's Tomorrowland shows, gotta wonder about the influences on the Space  Program.  Almost makes you regret that science fiction ever grew up.
Title: N/A
